subject: Economics
title: Piketty's r > g: Capital Eats the Economy
description: A micro-lesson that makes Piketty's r > g: Capital Eats the Economy usable.

hook.text: Thomas Piketty's 700-page book can be summarized in three characters: r > g. Return on capital exceeds economic growth.

buildup.text: If your investments grow at 5% and the economy grows at 2%, the rich get richer faster than everyone else.

discovery.text: Piketty analyzed 200 years of data across 20 countries.

twist.text: World wars and progressive taxation compressed wealth in the 20th century.

climax.text: r > g means capitalism, left alone, produces dynastic wealth. The solution Piketty proposes: a global wealth tax.

punchline.text: Capital grows faster than the economy. Unless you tax it.

quiz.question: What does Piketty's formula 'r > g' mean?
options: The return on capital exceeds economic growth, causing wealth to concentrate automatically over time
Rich countries grow faster than poor ones
